awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Genome-enabled Investigation of S(0) Cycling in a Subterranean Microbial Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbial-mineral interactions are ubiquitous and crucial aspects of geochemical cycling at the Earth's surface. Significant progress has been made towards identifying how specific groups of microorganisms interact with minerals, especially Fe oxides. However, there has been little work on how microbes make and break elemental sulfur (S(0)), though geologists have postulated microbial involvement in producing economic S(0) deposits. Chemical and biological controls on this process are not well understood, and will require a better understanding of factors affecting S(0) production and consumption within microbial biofilms.

Sulfur-cycling in the deep subsurface Frasassi cave system has been the target of several previous investigations due to its unique biogeochemistry and relative accessibility to human exploration. The cave ecosystem is sustained by microbial chemosynthesis taking place near the surface of its perenially sulfidic and microoxic aquifer. Conspicuous white biofilms in the cave waters contain 20 to 80% elemental sulfur by mass. Thus its geochemical and microbiological features make Frasassi a promising system for investigating microbial interactions with S(0), an important solid-phase intermediate in the sulfur cycle. Enigmatic Epsilonproteobacteria from the globally distributed and largely uncultivated Sulfurovumales clade are major players in Frassasi biofilms. They are especially abundant in waters with high sulfide and low oxygen supply, conditions which should lead to S(0) accumulation due to limited availability of electron acceptors. Using Frasassi biofilms and enrichment cultures as a model system, investigators are combining metatranscriptomics, correlative electron microscopy, and geochemistry with field and laboratory experiments to develop new understanding of S(0)-accumulating biofilm communities. This research will improve understanding of (i) the microbial role in producing geologic S(0) deposits; (ii) mechanisms for microbial interactions with solid phase S(0); and (iii) the metabolic capabilities of currently uncultured Epsilonproteobacteria. The research supports the long-term goal of integrating genetic and geochemical understanding of modern and ancient S biogeochemistry.

Project funds provide for the mentoring of two graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar. The proposed project provides outstanding opportunities for outreach to the general public due to interest in caves and extreme microbes. Images and microbial cultures from the project will be utilized in two highly successful annual events: PSU Exploration Day and PSU Geosciences Dept. "Shake, Rattle, Rocks". These events reach more than 2000 K-12 students and parents last year and 150 third grade students. Project microslide cultures will be incorporated into a hands-on grade 6-12 teacher workshop and the College of Earth, Ocean and Environment's annual Coast Day on the Lewes campus, a 34-year tradition that now attracts thousands of community members. Results will also be shared as part of the DE Sea Grant At Sea newsletter, and Sea Talk radio segments on NPR.

por.por_cntn:
Microbial-mineral interactions are ubiquitous and crucial aspects of geochemical cycling at the Earth's surface. Significant progress has been made towards identifying how specific groups of microorganisms interact with minerals, especially Fe oxides. However, there has been little work on how microbes make and break elemental sulfur (S(0)), though geologists have postulated microbial involvement in producing economic S(0) deposits. S-oxidizing microorganisms form S(0) as a byproduct, either inside or outside the cell. We are particularly interested in microbes that form extracellular S(0), as this is available for geochemical and ecological interactions, and may lead to geological sulfur deposits. Therefore, the objectives of this study were to determine how microbial communities make extracellular S(0) and the composition of the resulting minerals. To do this, we carried out a series of culture- and field-based experiments, along with geochemical, microscopy, and genomics analyses.

This work centered on the Frasassi cave ecosystem, where microbial life is sustained exclusively by chemical energy in the perennially sulfidic and microoxic cave streams. Floating atop the water, lush white streamer biofilms contain 20 to 80% elemental sulfur (S(0)) by mass, suggesting a microbial biomineralization process. We set up colonization devices and sampled over the course of 17 days to follow the development of the S(0)-rich streamers. The streams were high in dissolved sulfide but low in oxygen; we also detected polysulfide, a known product of microbial sulfide oxidation, and can spontaneously convert to S(0). These streamers were formed by an Epsilonbacteraeota Sulfurovum, as confirmed by 16S rRNA gene and metagenomic analyses. Over time, they developed a community of the Gammaproteobacteria Halothiobacillaceae, as well as other Epsilonproteobacteraeota Sulfuricurvum and Arcobacter. We assessed the biogeochemical contributions of the streamer communities by analyzing for specific genes in the community metagenomes, individual organism genomes, and transcriptomes. The vast majority of the organisms are autotrophic S-oxidizers, using the energy of sulfide oxidation for primary production. The organisms showed high expression of S(0)-forming genes, relative to S(0)-consuming genes, consistent with the accumulation of elemental S(0) in these streamer biofilms. The high expression of terminal oxidase genes suggests that the streamers specifically colonize the air-water interface in order to maximize access to oxygen. In sum, the main metabolism sustaining the streamers is aerobic sulfur oxidation, largely the partial oxidation resulting in elemental S(0).

To better understand the formation and geochemistry of the microbial elemental sulfur, we followed biomineralization by cultures of two Epsilonbacteraeota isolates, Sulfurimonas hongkongensis and Sulfuricurvum kujiense. These organisms formed extracellular S(0) as globules at a distance from the cells, a soluble intermediate. Indeed, we detected polysulfide in culture during the S(0) formation phase, implying that polysulfide is a transient intermediate, as we observed in the cave. In support of this, Raman spectroscopy analyses showed that the biogenic S(0) was composed of α-S8 (the common crystal form of elemental sulfur), but not polysulfide, suggesting that the polysulfide spontaneously transforms to S8 in the process of globule formation. X-ray diffraction showed that the biogenic S(0) globules are in fact aggregates of tiny nanometer-size crystals of α-S8. This is similar to other microbial biomineralization systems, which produce nanocrystals that are more reactive than larger bulk crystals. However, in both cultures and Frasassi streamer biofilms, we also observed another population of larger, micron-size rhombic S(0) crystals alongside the globules of nanocrystalline S(0). The larger crystals were more recalcitrant, and appeared to be an aging product when sulfide catalyzed recrystallization of the nano-S8. This suggests that in environments with a high sulphide flux, biogenic S(0) quickly ages and therefore has the potential to persist over longer periods of time. 

Overall, we found that the combination of S-oxidizing bacterial activity and abiotic chemical processes work together to rapidly produce abundant elemental sulfur in subsurface environments. Our work has resulted in an integrated understanding of the microbial players, processes, and geochemical conditions that promote biogenic sulfur formation, allowing us to more confidently describe the role of S-oxidizing bacteria in producing geologic sulfur deposits. This gives us deeper insight into the interconnection between biological and geological processes, and how these work together to form Earth’s resources.

This project provided training for a biology graduate student and female geomicrobiology postdoc in interdisiplinary approaches, specifically integrating genomic analyses with field-based biogeochemical research. We have used the ideas and results in the Microbes in the Wild outreach curriculum at the Serviam Academy in Wilmington, DE. This workshop introduce 5th­-8th grade girls to geo/environmental microbiology using a combination of soil sampling, culturing, and microscopy. Other outreach included science communication education at Havre de Grace high school, public outreach at our annual marine science festival Coast Day, and school tours of our Biotechnology institute.
